title: 115_s352
content: The Act may be cited as the "Master Sergeant Roddie Edmonds Congressional Gold Medal Act". Congress finds that Roddie Edmonds, a Master Sergeant in the US Army during WWII, was captured by Nazi forces in 1944 and detained in Stalag IX-A, a prisoner of war camp in Germany where Jewish soldiers were segregated and removed. During WWII, Master Sergeant Roddie Edmonds defied Nazi orders by refusing to segregate Jewish-American soldiers from their fellow prisoners at Stalag IX-A, where he was responsible for 1,275 members of the Armed Forces. All of his men stood together in solidarity outside their prison barracks. During WWII, Master Sergeant Roddie Edmonds defied Nazi orders by refusing to segregate Jewish-American soldiers at Stalag IX-A. When a German officer threatened him, Edmonds stood his ground, citing the Geneva Convention. His actions saved approximately 200 Jewish-American soldiers. During WWII, Master Sergeant Roddie Edmonds defied Nazi orders by refusing to segregate Jewish-American soldiers at Stalag IX-A. Lester Tanner, a Jewish-American member of the Armed Forces captured during the Battle of the Bulge, witnessed the incident. Edmonds risked his life to save the Jewish prisoners, and later served in Korea before passing away in 1985. Master Sergeant Roddie Edmonds defied Nazi orders during WWII by refusing to segregate Jewish-American soldiers at Stalag IX-A. He risked his life to save the prisoners and was posthumously recognized by Yad Vashem as "Righteous Among the Nations". Edmonds' actions set an example for his fellow American soldiers in standing against the Nazis. The Speaker of the House and the Senate President will arrange for a posthumous Congressional Gold Medal for Roddie Edmonds for his heroic actions in WWII. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the medal. It will be presented to Edmonds' next of kin. Duplicate medals may be made. The Secretary is authorized to produce and sell duplicate bronze medals of the gold medal created under section 3. These medals are considered national medals and numismatic items under specific sections of the United States Code.
